text.p: Voters in India's northern state of Punjab cast ballots peacefully on Friday in elections that were expected to thrust a pro-Sikh party into power.
The state's chief electoral officer Brajendra Singh said except for minor skirmishes between supporters of the ruling Congress party and its arch-rival Akali Dal party, polling had been trouble-free.

Officials said the elections to the 117-seat Punjab state legislature were the first in two decades not overshadowed by Sikh separatist violence. Some 65 percent of eligible voters cast ballots, Singh said.
India poured in 100,000 paramilitary soldiers to oversee elections. Police tightened security and sealed the borders of Punjab state with Pakistan.
Punjab police chief Sube Singh said all vehicles entering the rich farming region were searched for weapons.
Most opinion polls have predicted a victory for former chief minister Prakash Singh Badal's pro-Sikh Akali Dal party.

Surjit Singh Barnala, the last Akali Dal member to serve as Punjab chief minister and a member of the federal parliament, said his party was pleased with the relatively high turnout and predicted it would win at least 85 of 117 assembly seats.
Even the ruling Congress party admitted it would lose its majority. The party won 87 seats in February 1992, mainly because of an Akali Dal boycott.
But Congress politicians were sanguine. "No party is expected to get a majority," said Malkiat Singh Dakha, a minister in the outgoing government and Congress candidate from a Ludhiana constituency.
Voters hailed the return of peace to Punjab.
"This is the first time I have dared to vote in an election," said Shailendra Kumar, a 30-year-old car mechanic, as he waited for his turn at a polling booth in Ludhiana.
Sikh separatist violence peaked after Indian troops were sent into the Golden Temple in Amritsar in 1984 to flush out militants holed up in the Sikhs' holiest shrine.

The showdown triggered a bloody spate of violence in the state. The then prime minister Indira Gandhi was killed by two Sikh bodyguards on October 31, 1984, in what was believed to be a revenge killing for the army assault.
State polls in 1992, which revived local democracy after more than a decade of separatist violence, were held in an environment of fear and overbearing security.
The counting of ballots in Punjab is expected to start on Sunday and results are likely to be announced on the same day, officials said.
